title.narrative: UBUTABERA BWEGEREYE UMUTURAGE (Strengthening Proximity justice), UBU project

description.narrative: Goal 1) Strengthen Access to Justice by increasing Justice Recipients’ (especially women and vulnerable groups) knowledge of their basic rights and the functioning of the proximity justice system, allowing them to claim their rights. Improving the ability of Justice Providers (including state actors and CSOs) to deliver high quality justice services, to inform the population of their rights and the functioning of the justice system, and to support citizens (especially women and vulnerable groups) to exercise their rights. Public satisfaction with the services of justice providers will consequently increase. Goal 2) Build the capacity of CSOs in the justice sector to conduct advocacy in the interest of influencing positive change in the justice system, especially for the promotion of gender equality and women’s empowerment, for the benefit of the population (especially women and vulnerable groups). CSOs will undertake more advocacy initiatives.

participating-org.narrative: Switzerland - Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC)

activity-date.narrative: No Cost Extension signed between RCNJ&D and EKN has changed prolonged project implementation from 31/12/2021 to 30/06/2022, with an additional fund of Suiss Agency of Development Co-operation.

recipient-country.narrative: Funded via the Embassy of the Kingdom of Netherlands in Rwanda

provider-org.narrative: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation

title.narrative: Research on proximity justice findings shared stakeholders.

description.narrative: A research will be conducted on access to justice; 500 copies of the publication will be distributed and one conference organised. it will be a national advocacy.

title.narrative: Percentage of representatives of relevant institutions attended ( compared to invited) the conference to present research findings.
Number of copies of the research findings report received by relevant stakeholders.

description.narrative: Publication will be distributed among stakeholders including public institutions, development partners and CSOs.

comment.narrative: 500 copies will be printed but report will be also available online
A conference will be organized for the presentation of findings and distribution will be done after.

title.narrative: Capacity of conflict prevention/resolution mechanisms (conciliators committees (Abunzi), Sector Executive Secretaries, MAJ, District JRLOS Committees) strengthened

description.narrative:
Conciliators Committees will be coached by Primary courts judges and district MAJ (Maison d'Accès la la Justice in French, this is Access to Justice Bureaus in English). Follow-up visits will be organized at workplace to shape acquired performance for those Conciliators; through them MAJ will be mentored and coached to carry out coaching.
District JRLOS committees will be facilitated to discuss justice Sector development at district level, in district exchange workshops, and priorities will be identified to be taken into account in District planning.

title.narrative: Number of Abunzi trained through educational resources via mobile phone

description.narrative: It is expected that 2,912 Conciliators are trained from 416 Conciliators committees are trained through basic mobile phone.

title.narrative: Number of MAJ (Maison d'Accès à la Justice) strengthened to carry out coaching of Conciliator committees

description.narrative:
At the beginning, RCN J&D specialists were carrying out coaching to Conciliators committees. MAJ (acronym of Maison d'Accès à la Justice in French, this is Access to Justice Bureaus in English) were mentored and coached by those specialists in training and coaching methodology. For now MAJ are acquiring capacities to carry out coaching and to measure Abunzi peformance, using Tools developed by RCN J&D.
MAJ are coordinating legal aid at district level including Conciliator committees mechanisms. Every MAJ has three agents who provide legal aid. the coordinator of MAJ is qualified as Lawyer for legal representation of low income justice recipients; the second member is qualified as Non professional bailiff at district level and support low income litigants to execute justice decisions; the third member of MAJ is is in charge of Conciliators committees and treatment of SGBV cases

comment.narrative: MAJ agents in 6 districts of Rwanda, Kayonza nd Ngoma in the Eastern province, Nyabihu, Karongi and Rutsiro in the Western province, and Nyanza in Southern province were strengthened to carry out coaching throuth, through workshops and visits of Abunzi at workplace. they can do it without RCN J&D specialist and coach other MAJ not supported by the project. the main remaining barrier is logistic for them to regularly visit Conciliator workspace. One MAJ in Kicukiro district (Kigali City) was not coached because of the availability of MAJ, because majority of Conciliators committees, in urban area, are working during the Week End.

title.narrative: Participation rate of Abunzi committees (Conciliators) and Executives secretaries coached by Judges and MAJ

description.narrative: It is expected that 84 Abunzi committees (Conciliators) will be coached in workshops by judges and Ministry of justice Bureaus (MAJ=Maisons d'Accès à la Justice) at district level. This will make 588 Abunzi and 84 executive Secretaries.

comment.narrative: 581 participants (out of 672 expected) are coached by judges in phase 1. This includes 493 conciliators, 42 Executive Secretaries, 26 civil registrars representative of executive secretaries and 6 Good governance officers also representative of Executive Secretaries. Executive secretaries have a key legal role to record Conciliators cases and all related bailiffs roles.
Phase 2 of coaching: 147 participants attended out of 672 expected, including 137 Conciliators and 10 Executives Secretaries. the activity is ongoing.

title.narrative: Participation of Abunzi committees (Conciliators) and executive Secretaries coached at workplace per phase.

description.narrative: The follow-up visit at workplace records the attendance rate of Abunzi and Executive Secretary. The objective of this visit is to shape assess and strengthen the acquired capacities in coaching workshops.

comment.narrative: After coaching by judges, coachs from District Justice Bureaus, called Maison d'Accès à la Justice (MAJ) and RCN J&D teams of specialists in training and coaching have visited every committee at workplace and the day of conciliation. Phase one results: For 84 follow up visits to be conducted, for a total of 588 conciliators, 77 were done. 414 Conciliators (Female: 181 (43.72%) ; Male: 233) have attended coaching at workplace.

after phase 2 of coaching by judges (ongoing at the date of reporting), conciliators committees already coached are being visited at workplace. 12 out of 84 committees are already visited, 51 conciliators including 23 (45.10%) women and 28 men are coached.

title.narrative: Number of District JRLOS committees strengthened

description.narrative: Through district exchange workshops, districts JRLOS committees (DJC) will be facilitated to identify priorities in their district and to integrate them in District planning. District JRLOS Committee plays the role of justice sector development at district level. It include, as members executive and judiciary officials (Access to Justice Bureau, District Notary, Prosecutors, Police, Rwanda Investigation Bureau), two CSOs representatives and private legal practitioners (bailiffs and lawyers).

comment.narrative: At the date of reporting, RCN J&D has organised this activity in collaboration with Central JRLOS Secretariat. Workshop will be organised involving all stakeholders at district level including JRLOS committees, district authorities and security organs at district level.

title.narrative: Citizens were informed through UBU legal aid activities (Justice Caravan, Community Dialogues, mobile phones, print IEC materials).

description.narrative: Desegregation by sex is not possible for justice caravan, due to a great number of participants. in 2019, 46000 citizens attended 18 tours of justice caravan in six districts. and in December 2019, the content on judgement execution was added to MTN 845 (telephone number used by VIAMO), to the content added by legal aid forum, on legal information, particularly on family law and GBV prevention. on 31 December 2020, Participants in 2020 including 5980 participants in community dialogues; 84819 Followers of sketches on phone: (those who have Followed over two minutes (120 seconds) With 46000 have participated in justice caravans’ tours in 2019, the progress is 136799, this is

title.narrative: Number of informed participants through legal awareness (desegregated by used channels: Justice Caravan, Community Dialogues, Mobisodes).

comment.narrative: Informed citizens : in 2021 additional legal public awareness activities were community dialogues: the total of participants are 140656 in 2021 including 6813 in community dialogues in 2020 and 2021; 87843 Followers of sketches on phone: (those who have Followed over two minutes (120 seconds) With 46000 have participated in justice caravans tours in 2019

title.narrative: CSOs members of JRLOS District Committees developed their capacity in advocacy for Access to justice in Rwanda

description.narrative: In 30 Districts, two CSOs members of JRLOS committees are strengthened receiving technical skills, networking and developing policies and advocacy initiatives.

title.narrative: Number of CSOs with advocacy policies and strategies developed with UBU project support.

description.narrative: Some of the CSOs will be supported to develop advocacy policy and strategy documents. Criteria will be set by the consortium members for selection purposes.

comment.narrative: Two CSOs have already advocacy policy and strategy documents developed with RCN Justice & Démocratie financial support before UBU Project.

The two organizations, Haguruka and Tubibe Amahoro, have already policies remain District JRLOS committees members, in different districts. four others CSOS were selected. their policies and strategies are under development with the support of the project (a consultant was hired to facilitate them).

title.narrative: Average participation in capacity building events on advocacy for access to justice by CSOs members of JRLOS district committees. in 2019 the average participation rate in networking meeting was 54.9%. in 2020 one networking meeting held have involved CSOs leaders and have identified needs in advocacy capacity building. 20 (F=4, M=16) out of 34 CSO leaders participated in a special networking meeting. 45(F=15, M=30) out of 68 staff of CSOs in District JRLOS committees have participated in training on HR standards on detention and gender mainstreaming and anti GBV framework 44(F=15, M=29) out of 68 participated in training on advocacy strategic planning.

comment.narrative: 45(F=15, M=30) out of 68 staff of CSOs in District JRLOS committees have participated in training on HR standards on detention and gender mainstreaming and anti GBV framework 44(F=15, M=29) out of 68 participated in training on advocacy strategic planning, and 20 (F=4, M=16) out of 34 CSO leaders participated in a special networking meeting. Rate: 64,11%

Participants have participate in networking meeting and in dialogues on the role of civil society in Justice Sector. 60 CSO representatives (2) members from each District) were invited to participate to events organised with the view to strengthen their capacity in advocacy. This is the average attendance of the two events organised in 2019.

title.narrative: Number of evidence-based advocacy campaigns proposed to the consortium

description.narrative: CSOS member will be stimulated to develop advocacy campaigns. The most relevant will get financial support by the project to be implemented.

title.narrative: Justice recipients (citizens) informed claim/exercise their rights or respect rights of others and help others in their community to do so, and are solving themselves conflict using acquired information

description.narrative: Justice Recipients are active citizens who share and debate their own experiences, expectations, recommendations and knowledge with Proximity Justice users and service providers. They have knowledge of their basic rights and the administration of proximity justice allowing them to exercise these rights. They are confident that they can defend their rights and do so before appropriate judicial authorities. Justice Recipients take steps in support of more equitable conditions for women and vulnerable groups to access justice services to exercise their rights.

title.narrative: Proportion of respondents recognising to solve conflict themselves due to received information form the project event (justice caravan, community dialogue and radio programs)

comment.narrative: The Evaluation conducted in December 2019 and in February 2021 on sample of 942 respondents. 18.69%v of respondents have changed behaviour by solving their own conflicts.

title.narrative: Proportion of informed citizens Through UBU public awareness helped others to claim/exercise rights.

description.narrative: Participants in public awareness events were stimulated to share and support others in their community, using acquired legal information

comment.narrative: The sample for the evaluation includes 50% of men and 50% of women

title.narrative: Capacities of Non professional bailiffs strengthened to reduce judgement execution backlogs.

description.narrative: Non professional bailiffs are state agents and include Executive Secretaries of Cell, Sector and District, Ministry of Justice District Access to Justice Bureaus (MAJ). They provide justice decision enforcement services free of charge. Their capacity building activities are conducted In each of the six districts covered by UBU project.

title.narrative: Participation rate of non-professional bailiffs in district exchanges on judgement enforcement.

description.narrative: All Non professional bailiffs are invited to attend district exchange workshop where barriers on judgement enforcement are discussed, solutions suggested and good practices shared. Professionals bailiffs are invite to update the participants' knowledge. in 2019, participation rate was 83.3%. in 2020, 2020, 124 nonprofessional bailiffs out of 125 expected (rate: 99.2%) (F=50; M :74) Have participated in exchange and coaching on their work . This coaching has supported them to have to handle the use f IECMS with was used by judges, prosecutor and lawyers only. Since last year laws changed and enforcement of decision will be done through this online system.

comment.narrative: Invited authorities are 450 from all entities. they represent 100%.

title.narrative: Paralegals from partner CSOs have built capacities to conduct legal aid activities

description.narrative: Paralegals are recruited and employed by CSOs as Legal aid providers at District level. there are one legal officer and assistant at each of the six districts. In addition they have one volunteer paralegal in every sector from the 6 districts providing legal aid.

title.narrative: Number of paralegal trained

description.narrative: Sector and district paralegals are trained and refreshed or well conduct legal aid activities in their respective districts and sectors

comment.narrative:
During 2020, 77 paralegals were trained. 54 received a refresher training (Nyanza, Kayonza, Karongi and Rutsiro districts) and 23 have received the first training (Kicukiro and Ngoma districts). 47 (61%) paralegals are women and 30 (39%) are men.
in 2021 sector paralegals were trained on reporting tools developed to facilitate their work.
Paralegals were recruited and trained for four (4) districts on six (6). A new partner, Lawyers of Hope, replacing ancient partner dropped out is recruiting paralegals to be trained.

title.narrative: Proximity justice actors have improved capacities

description.narrative: Proximity justice actors have the necessary knowledge and materials that allow them to deliver high quality justice services in conformity with their mandate and human rights principles. Proximity Justice actors collaborate to allow each other to fulfill their mandates. Proximity justice actors inform and support the population about their rights and the functioning of the justice system so citizens, especially women and vulnerable groups, are able to exercise these rights. CSOs implement advocacy campaigns, including the promotion of gender equality and women’s empowerment, which result in positive impact for the justice sector, including policy and legislative changes.

title.narrative: Average performance of Conciliator committees and Executive Secretaries

description.narrative: By observation methods and collecting administrative data to conciliator committees (CC) and Executive Secretary at workplace, a score is attributed based on specific performance criteria. These results will be obtained by evaluating the quality of fulfillment of responsibilities of Abunzi committees, at appeal level, using a performance evaluation sheet of five levels: the score is zero, if the act is not posed; the score is between 0 and 5 if the performance is not good enough; the score between 5 and 8 if the performance is good; the score between 8 and 10 if the performance is excellent.

comment.narrative: For Baseline, the Abunzi performance of 54.52% is passable (between 50 and 80%); the Executive Secretary performance of 42.3% is not good enough (between 0 and 50%).
the performance should be increased by, at least 5%
Actual value equal baseline

title.narrative: Proportion of beneficiaries (sample) recognizing satisfaction of proximity justice services

description.narrative: Level of satisfaction is measured for those who have benefited from proximity justice services in five scales (Lickert scale). face-to-face and mobile phone surveys will be used.

comment.narrative: Totally satisfied: 48.6%; satisfied at a great extent: 21.4%; a Bit satisfied: 10.4%; not enough satisfied: 8%; not satisfied at all: 11.6%.
Actual value equal baseline

title.narrative: Number CSOs-led advocacy initiatives for access to justice policy change

description.narrative: Civil society organizations are reinforced to change organizational practices to influence policy changes by increasing advocacy initiatives.

comment.narrative: If lots of initiatives are conducted and supported by the project, it is expected that CSOs individually or in network will conduct at least two initiatives, without a direct support from the project but rather using acquired technical capacities.

title.narrative: Proportion of Justice decisions enforcement compared to total requests in a judicial year

description.narrative: This indicator intended to measure if execution backlog is reduced by measuring increase of judgement execution rate. it will be informed in six district covered by the project in Rwanda for cases processed by non professional bailiffs only, as proximity justice actors.

comment.narrative: Waiting for official actual value in July, the baseline, as Last year Ministry of Justice value is actual value

title.narrative: Proportion of Primary courts' judgement confirming Conciliation Committee decisions in a judicial year.

description.narrative: Primary court, examines complaints submitted by parties not satisfied at Conciliators committees appeal level. If Primary court judges confirm their decision, it means Abunzi have well solved it. By coaching Abunzi proportion of judgments confirming Abunzi decision should increase.

comment.narrative: Equal value equal baseline

title.narrative: Individual cases of justice recipients are treated by legal aid provision services managed by CSOs, supported by UBU project in six districts and in legal aid events

description.narrative: Those are cases processed by district paralegals of CSOs Legal aid clinics including Haguruka in three districts and Tubibe Amahoro in two districts.

title.narrative: Number of individuals benefited from legal aid provision services.

description.narrative: Those are received in district CSO offices or during any public awareness event

comment.narrative:
Legal aid provision is provided by three CSs partners in seven (7) districts.
Cases processed include those submitted for women and girls: 2544 (62.83%) of all cases; Cases submitted for Men beneficiaries: 1505. the progress for this indicator is 53.91%.

title.narrative: Number legal aid cases of Girls and women supported to submit court cases or for forensic expertise

description.narrative: Women and girl cases will receive a Lawyer for a legal representation before courts and should have additional support for expertise, particularly, DNA expertise will can be payed when the the Court will obligate it.

comment.narrative: 3o cases are already supported. majority of them are yet pending.
